lcInstruction.p: Bookmaps extend the functionality of maps by providing elements that allow you to create book-like structures, such as chapters, frontmatter, and backmatter. Although maps and bookmaps share a similar structure, bookmaps contain a more expansive set of elements, which provide many more options for preparing your content for publicationâ€”particularly if you have large amounts of it. This makes bookmaps better suited to publishing content in book format, and more flexible than maps overall.

When you're deciding whether to compile your topics into a map or a bookmap, your publication and delivery process should be a major factor. If you need to deliver your content in print or PDF form, it is generally recommended that you use bookmaps instead of maps. Maps are sufficient for online distribution, but bookmaps are better if you plan to publish in both print and electronic formats.

One of the main differences between bookmaps and maps is the ability to have chapters in a bookmap. In a map, you can nest second-level topics under a first-level topic to create a hierarchy. In a bookmap, you can designate these first-level topics as container topics for chapters. Although the hierarchical structure of topics is the same, there is added semantic value in calling a first-level topic and the topics contained within it a chapter. When you publish the same set of topics in a map versus a bookmap, your output transforms can apply different styling based on the presence of chapters.

Bookmaps also give you much more flexible options than maps for defining metadata. You can define metadata in the bookmap, in the frontmatter and backmatter, and in each chapter, topic reference, or map reference you add to the bookmap. There are more metadata elements available for bookmaps than there are for maps, and many of these elements are specific to book-like structures and therefore better suited to publishing your content.

A bookmap is a DITA map file that uses the <bookmap> element rather than the <map> element as a container for its topic and map references. While maps and bookmaps have a similar structure, a bookmap contains a different and more expansive set of elements. This makes it more flexible and better suited to publishing larger amounts of content in book format.
